entry.et: Middle English owen, from Old English āgen; akin to Old High German eigan own, Old Norse eiginn, Old English āgan to possess owe

def.dt: :belonging to oneself or itself usually used following a possessive case or possessive adjective cooked my own dinner

dt.un: used to express immediate or direct kinship an own son an own sister

def.dt: :to have or hold as property :possess
:to have power or mastery over wanted to own his own life
:to acknowledge to be true, valid, or as claimed :admit own a debt
:to acknowledge something to be true, valid, or as claimed used with to or up

entry.fl: pronoun, singular or plural in construction

def.dt: :one or ones belonging to oneself used after a possessive and without a following noun gave out books so that each of us had our own a room of your own
:for or by oneself :independently of assistance or control made the decision on his own
:left to rely entirely on one's own resources if you mess up, you're on your own

entry.et: Middle English acounte, accompte, from Anglo-French acunte, from acunter

def.dt: :reckoning computation
:a record of debit and credit entries to cover transactions involving a particular item or a particular person or concern
:a statement of transactions during a fiscal period and the resulting balance
:a statement explaining one's conduct
:a statement or exposition of reasons, causes, or motives no satisfactory account of these phenomena
:a reason for an action :basis on that account I must refuse
:a formal business arrangement providing for regular dealings or services (as banking, advertising, or store credit) and involving the establishment and maintenance of an account
:client customer
:money deposited in a bank account and subject to withdrawal by the depositor
:value importance it's of no account to me
:esteem stood high in their account
:advantage turned her wit to good account
:careful thought :consideration have to take many things into account
:a usually mental record :track keep account of all you do
:a description of facts, conditions, or events :report narrative the newspaper account of the fire by all accounts they're well-off
:performance a straightforward account of the sonata
:with the price charged to one's account
:for the sake of :by reason of
:under no circumstances
:on one's own behalf
:at one's own risk
:by oneself :on one's own

entry.et: Middle English, from Old English batt

def.dt: :a stout solid stick :club
:a sharp blow :stroke
:a usually wooden implement used for hitting the ball in various games
:a paddle used in various games (as table tennis)
:the short whip used by a jockey
:batsman batter a right-handed bat
:a turn at batting usually used in the phrase at bat
:hitting ability we need his bat in the lineup
:batt
:rate of speed :gait
:binge
:through one's own efforts
:without delay :immediately recognized him right off the bat

entry.et: probably alteration of Middle English bakke, of Scandinavian origin; akin to Old Swedish nattbakka bat

def.dt: :any of a widely distributed order (Chiroptera) of nocturnal usually frugivorous or insectivorous flying mammals that have wings formed from four elongated digits of the forelimb covered by a cutaneous membrane and that have adequate visual capabilities but often rely on echolocation

entry.et: Middle English, from Latin, from com-; akin to Old English ge-, perfective and collective prefix, Old Irish com- with

def.dt: :with :together :joint :jointly coexist coheir
:in or to the same degree coextensive
:one that is associated in an action with another :fellow :partner coauthor coworker
:having a usually lesser share in duty or responsibility :alternate :deputy copilot
:of, relating to, or constituting the complement of an angle cosine

entry.et: Middle English, from Old English cuman; akin to Old High German queman to come, Latin venire, Greek bainein to walk, go

def.dt: :to move toward something :approach come here
:to move or journey to a vicinity with a specified purpose come see us come and see what's going on
:to reach a particular station in a series now we come to the section on health
:to arrive in due course the time has come
:to approach in kind or quality this comes near perfection
:to reach a condition or conclusion came to regard him as a friend come to think of it, you may be right
:to advance toward accomplishment :come along the job is coming nicely
:to advance in a particular manner come running when I call
:to advance, rise, or improve in rank or condition has come a long way
:extend her dress came to her ankles
:to arrive at a particular place, end, result, or conclusion came to his senses come untied
:amount the taxes on it come to more than it's worth
:to appear to the mind the answer came to them
:to appear on a scene :make an appearance children come equipped to learn any language
:happen occur no harm will come to you
:to come to pass :take place used in the subjunctive with inverted subject and verb to express the particular time or occasion come spring the days will be longer
:originate arise wine comes from grapes they come of sturdy stock
:to enter or assume a condition, position, or relation artillery came into action
:to fall within a field of view or a range of application this comes within the terms of the treaty
:to issue forth a sob came from her throat
:to take form churn till the butter comes
:to be available this model comes in several sizes as good as they come
:to experience orgasm
:to fall to a person in a division or inheritance of property
:to become moved favorably :relent
:to turn out to be good clothes don't come cheap
:become a dream that came true
:to approach or be near (an age) a child coming eight years old
:to take on the aspect of come the stern parent
:to fail completely the plan came a cropper
:to meet, find, or encounter especially by chance researchers have come across important new evidence
:repeat
:to speak further used as an interrogative
:to tell the whole story :confess came clean about her crimes
:to acquire as a possession or achievement come into a fortune
:to achieve one's potential
:to gain recognition
:to reach maturity
:to cease foolish or pretentious talk or behavior
:to seize suddenly and strangely what's come over you
:to be a question of when it comes to pitching horseshoes, he's the champ
:to encounter misfortune (as calamity, defeat, or ruin) his campaign came to grief
:to meet or deal with firmly, frankly, or straightforwardly come to grips with the unemployment problem
:to get hold of oneself :regain self-control
:happen
:to reach an agreement often used with with the company has come to terms with the union
:to become adjusted especially emotionally or intellectually usually used with with come to terms with modern life
:to meet or find by chance :come across came upon an old friend
:existing or arriving in the future in the days to come there will be more trouble to come

entry.et: alteration of hysse to hoist, perhaps from Low German hissen

def.dt: :hoist 1
:victimized or hurt by one's own scheme

entry.et: Middle English, from Old English healdan; akin to Old High German haltan to hold, and perhaps to Latin celer rapid, Greek klonos agitation

def.dt: :to have possession or ownership of or have at one's disposal holds property worth millions the bank holds the title to the car
:to have as a privilege or position of responsibility hold a professorship
:to have as a mark of distinction holds the record for the 100-yard dash holds a PhD
:to keep under restraint hold price increases to a minimum: as
:to prevent free expression of hold your temper
:to prevent from some action ordered the troops to hold fire the only restraining motive which may hold the hand of a tyrant Thomas Jefferson
:to keep back from use ask them to hold a room for us I'll have a hot dog, and hold the mustard
:to delay temporarily the handling of please hold all my calls
:to make liable or accountable or bound to an obligation I'll hold you to your promise
:to have or maintain in the grasp hold my hand this is how you hold the racket
:aim point held a gun on them
:to support in a particular position or keep from falling or moving hold me up so I can see hold the ladder steady a clamp holds the whole thing together hold your head up
:to bear the pressure of :support can the roof hold all of that weight
:to prevent from leaving or getting away hold the train: as
:to avoid emitting or letting out how long can you hold your breath
:to restrain as or as if a captive the suspect was held without bail held them at gunpoint
:to have strong appeal to the book held my interest throughout
:to enclose and keep in a container or within bounds :contain the jug holds one gallon this corral will not hold all of the horses
:to be able to consume easily or without undue effect can't hold any more pie
:to be able to drink (alcoholic beverages) without becoming noticeably drunk can't hold your liquor
:accommodate the restaurant holds 400 diners
:to have as a principal or essential feature or attribute the book holds a number of surprises
:to have in store no one knows what the future holds

:to have in the mind or express as a judgment, opinion, or belief I hold the view that this is wrong hold a grudge holding that it is nobody's business but his Jack Olsen often used with against in America they hold everything you say against you Paul McCartney
:to think of in a particular way :regard were held in high esteem
:to assemble for and carry on the activity of held a convention
:to cause to be carried on :conduct will hold a seminar
:to produce or sponsor especially as a public exhibition will hold an art show
:to maintain occupation, control, or defense of the troops held the ridge
:to resist the offensive efforts or advance of held the opposing team to just two points
:to maintain (a certain condition, situation, or course of action) without change hold a course due east
:to cover (a part of the body) especially for protection had to hold their ears because of the cold
:to maintain position :refuse to give ground the defensive line is holding
:to continue in the same way or to the same degree :last hopes the weather will hold often used with up
:to derive right or title often used with of or from
:to be or remain valid :apply the rule holds in most cases often used in the phrase hold true
:to maintain a grasp on something :remain fastened to something the anchor held in the rough sea
:to go ahead as one has been going held south for several miles
:to bear or carry oneself asked him to hold still
:to forbear an intended or threatened action :halt pause often used as a command
:to stop counting during a countdown
:to have illicit drug material in one's possession
:advocate defend usually used in negative constructions I hold no brief for cartels and market allocations J. D. Upham
:to qualify for comparison with
:to be the center of attention among friends or admirers
:to speak at length :expatiate
:to engage one's hand with another's especially as an expression of affection
:to prevent oneself from breathing temporarily
:to wait in anxious anticipation
:to slow down or stop for a moment usually used in the imperative
:to maintain one's position :prove equal to opposition
:to keep silent :keep one's thoughts to oneself
:to have a dominant influence :rule
:to be left empty-handed
:to bear alone a responsibility that should have been shared by others
:to maintain a firm position
:to take care of usual affairs is holding the fort until the manager returns
:to maintain the current position or situation hold the line on prices
:to give firm assent to :adhere to strongly holds to his promise
:to hold responsible
:to stand up under criticism or analysis
:to agree with or approve of
